Hi there, and thanks for your question.  The fact that you are feeling guilty after a night of drinking, even if you didn't do anything wrong, suggests that you may have a problem with drinking.  Drinking can affect your judgment and lead you to do things you might regret, and it can also lead to feelings of guilt.  It's a common experience for people who drink too much.  The fact that you are aware of your behavior and are seeking help is a good sign.  You might want to consider talking to a therapist about your drinking, and how you can better manage it.  It's also a good idea to talk to your boyfriend about your concerns, and see if he is aware of the impact your drinking is having on your relationship.  Good luck.

It is normal to feel nervous and shaky when you first start therapy, especially if it's your first time. However, if you're still feeling nervous and shaky after a few sessions, it may be worth discussing this with your therapist. They can help you understand why you're feeling this way and work with you to address any underlying issues that may be contributing to these feelings.

Hello and thanks for your question. It sounds like you're feeling guilty after drinking and that's a good thing! Guilt is a natural response to behaviors that we don't feel good about. However, if you're feeling guilty about drinking, it could be a sign that you're drinking too much or that you're not happy with the way you're behaving when you're drinking. It's good that you're aware of your feelings and that you're thinking about them. This is a great opportunity for you to think about your drinking and to make some positive changes. You may want to consider talking to a therapist or counselor about your drinking. They can help you think about your drinking and help you to make a plan to cut back or stop drinking. You may also want to think about what you can do to make your drinking more enjoyable and to make you feel good about yourself after you drink. For example, you might try to drink with people you care about, or you might try to drink less and to pace yourself. You might also want to think about what you're drinking and why you're drinking. Is it to relax, to have fun, or to fit in? If you can identify your motivations, you may be able to make some changes that will help you to feel better about your drinking. Finally, if you're feeling guilty about cheating on your boyfriend, you may want to think about why you're doing this. Are you feeling insecure or unhappy in your relationship? Are you feeling lonely or bored? If so, you may want to talk to your boyfriend about your feelings and to see if you can work through them together. Good luck! I hope this helps. Best regards, Jeanne King, LCSW, LCMFT.

I'm so sorry to hear that you're struggling with anxiety and depression. It can be frustrating to feel like you've tried everything and still haven't found what works for you. Hello and thank you for your question. It sounds like you're experiencing a form of auditory hallucination, which is a symptom of a psychiatric disorder known as schizophrenia. This can be a very scary and confusing experience. If you're hearing voices, it's possible that you're experiencing a psychotic episode, which is a symptom of schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is a chronic mental illness that affects how you think, feel, and behave. It can cause hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thinking. It can also cause you to feel anxious, depressed, and disconnected from the world around you. Schizophrenia is not caused by anything you or anyone else has done. It's not a personal failing. It's a brain disorder that can be treated with medication and therapy. Treatment can help you manage your symptoms and live a happy, healthy life. If you're experiencing any of the symptoms of schizophrenia, I would encourage you to seek help. You can start by talking to your primary care physician or a mental health professional. They can help you get the help you need to manage your symptoms.

It sounds like you are experiencing a form of a seizure. There are several types of seizures, and a seizure can manifest in many different ways. It's not uncommon for seizures to start out as a small, brief, and seemingly insignificant event that gradually escalates in intensity. It's not uncommon for people to experience seizures that are not noticed or reported by others. If you have had a benign brain tumor, it's possible that it has caused a seizure disorder. Consult with your doctor about this.

Hi, and thanks for your question. It is completely normal to have some anxiety about meeting new people. This can be especially true when you are in a large group of people. You may have a fear of embarrassing yourself, or fear that others are judging you. The first thing to do is to recognize that your fear is not the truth. Most people are too busy with their own lives to be thinking about you. They are probably too busy trying to get their own needs met to be paying attention to you. The second thing to do is to remind yourself that you are a valuable person, and that you have a lot to offer. This can help you to feel more confident in social situations. Another thing you can do is to prepare for the situation. If you are attending a party, you might think about the things you are going to say, and the things you are going to do. You might also consider talking to a trusted friend about your fears. Sometimes talking about your fears can help you to feel more prepared and more confident. Hello, and thanks for your question. I can't help but wonder if you've ever considered that your sexual orientation is not a fixed entity, but rather a spectrum.  Many people who identify as gay, lesbian, bisexual, or queer, have reported a change in their sexual orientation over time. This change can be due to a variety of reasons, such as changes in life circumstances, self-discovery, or even a reevaluation of one's identity.  It's also possible that you may be experiencing a same-sex attraction that doesn't necessarily mean you are gay. This is often referred to as "sexual fluidity."Sexual fluidity is the idea that people may experience same-sex attraction at times in their lives, but not identify as gay or lesbian. For example, you may be attracted to women at times, but also attracted to men. This can be confusing, especially if you have been in a long-term relationship with someone of the opposite sex.  If you are interested in exploring your feelings, I would encourage you to consider speaking with a therapist. A therapist can help you explore your feelings and provide support and guidance as you navigate your identity.  If you are interested in speaking with a therapist, I would be happy to provide a referral to a therapist in your area.  If you are interested in learning more about sexual fluidity, I would recommend checking out the book "The Highly Sensitive Person's Survival Guide" by Elaine Aron. The book explores the concept of sexual fluidity and provides information on how to navigate this fluidity.  I hope this helps. I would be happy to answer any other questions you may have.

Crying is a normal response to a variety of situations, including therapy. It is a way of expressing and releasing feelings of sadness, grief, or stress. Crying is a healthy way to express and release these feelings, rather than bottling them up. The act of crying can help to relieve tension, reduce stress, and promote healing. It is common for people to cry in therapy because they are finally able to express and process their feelings in a safe and supportive environment. Crying in therapy is a sign that the person is feeling comfortable and able to open up and be honest about their feelings. This is a positive sign and a good indicator that therapy is working. It is also common for people to cry during therapy because they are finally able to talk about traumatic or painful experiences that they have been holding inside. This can be a relief, and crying can be a way of releasing the emotional burden that has been weighing them down. It is not uncommon for people to feel a mix of emotions during therapy, including sadness, anger, and fear. Crying is a way of expressing these emotions and can be a way of healing and moving forward. It is also common for people to cry during therapy because they are feeling a sense of relief and hope. They may be feeling a sense of hope that they have not felt in a long time, and crying can be a way of releasing these feelings of hope and relief. Overall, crying in therapy is a normal response to a variety of situations and is a sign that the person is feeling comfortable and able to open up and be honest about their feelings. It is a positive sign and a good indicator that therapy is working. It is also important to note that it is not just you who cry in therapy. Many people cry in therapy, and it is a normal response to a variety of situations. If you are feeling uncomfortable about crying in therapy, you can talk to your therapist about it. They can help you to feel more comfortable and at ease during your sessions. It is also important to remember that crying is a healthy way to express and release feelings of sadness, grief, or stress. It is a way of healing and moving forward, and it is a sign that you are feeling comfortable and able to open up and be honest about your feelings.

Hello and thank you for your question. It sounds like your partner is using verbal abuse as a way to get what she wants. She is using anger as a way to control you. This is a very common tactic in abusive relationships. You may want to seek out a therapist who specializes in domestic violence. They can help you understand the dynamics of your relationship and help you determine if you are in a healthy relationship or not. In the meantime, here are some suggestions that might help you:1.  If you feel safe, you can talk to your partner about how her words make you feel. You can say something like, "I feel disrespected and hurt when you call me names. I want to talk about what's going on with you. Is there something bothering you that I can help with?"2.  If you don't feel safe, you may want to set boundaries. You can say something like, "I don't like it when you call me names. Please don't do that. If you're angry, I want to talk about it with you."3.  If you feel like you are in a healthy relationship, you may want to talk to your partner about counseling. If you don't feel like you are in a healthy relationship, you may want to seek out a therapist to talk about what you are feeling. I hope this helps. Good luck. Best regards, Linda Fox, LCSW, MFT

Hello, and thank you for your question. There is no one-size-fits-all answer to your question. Each couple is unique and has its own history, dynamics, and set of circumstances that affect the marriage. That being said, there are some general principles that can help couples build a healthy and long-lasting marriage. Some of the key principles include: Communication, respect, trust, intimacy, and commitment. Couples who have a strong and healthy marriage are able to communicate effectively, respect each other's differences, build and maintain trust, prioritize intimacy, and are committed to one another. They also have a strong sense of humor and are able to laugh together, and are able to forgive each other when mistakes are made. Couples who are able to work through conflicts in a healthy way are also more likely to have a long-lasting marriage. This involves being able to listen to each other, being able to express feelings and needs in a non-judgmental way, and being able to compromise. Couples also need to be able to prioritize their relationship and make time for each other, even in the midst of other responsibilities and demands. Couples who are able to maintain a sense of independence and autonomy, while also being connected to each other, are also more likely to have a long-lasting marriage. Couples who are able to work through difficult times together, and are able to find meaning and purpose in their relationship, are also more likely to have a long-lasting marriage. I hope this information helps. Best of luck to you.

Hi there, I'm glad you reached out for support. It takes a lot of courage to share that you're struggling with self-hatred. Self-hatred is a symptom of deeper issues. You may be feeling this way due to past experiences or current situations that are causing you distress. I would like to encourage you to seek professional help from a therapist or counselor. A therapist can help you work through these feelings and help you develop more positive self-talk. A therapist can also help you identify triggers and coping mechanisms that contribute to these feelings. In the meantime, here are a few suggestions that may help you feel more positive about yourself: Practice self-care. Take care of your physical health by eating well and exercising regularly. Get enough sleep and take time to relax and recharge. Practice self-compassion. Be kind and understanding with yourself. Try to reframe negative thoughts into positive ones. For example, instead of saying "I'm ugly," say "I'm a beautiful person inside and out." Practice mindfulness. Pay attention to the present moment and try to let go of worries about the past or future. Focus on your breath and the sensations in your body. Practice gratitude. Reflect on things you are thankful for each day. This can help shift your focus away from negative thoughts and towards positive ones. You are not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with self-hatred and low self-esteem. You can seek help and support to work through these feelings and develop a more positive self-image.

I'm so sorry you're going through this. It's not uncommon for people to feel numb after a traumatic experience, like rape. The good news is that you can work to change this. First, I want you to know that you're not a sociopath. It's not uncommon for people who have experienced trauma to feel disconnected from their emotions, but this is not the same as being a sociopath. Sociopaths typically lack empathy and are unable to feel emotions, while people who have experienced trauma may have a harder time accessing and expressing emotions. One thing you can do to help you feel more connected to your emotions is to practice mindfulness. Mindfulness is the practice of being present in the moment and focusing on your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This can help you become more aware of your emotions and your body. You can start by focusing on your breath. When you feel yourself getting caught up in thoughts, gently bring your attention back to your breath. Another thing you can do is to practice self-compassion. When you're feeling numb, it can be hard to feel compassionate towards yourself, but it's an important part of healing. Practice talking to yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would a good friend. If you're interested in learning more about mindfulness and self-compassion, I would recommend checking out the work of Dr. Kristin Neff and Dr. Mark Williams. They're both experts in the field of mindfulness and self-compassion and have many resources available. I hope this helps. I'm here to support you if you have any questions or concerns.

Children are just beginning to learn how to use their hands, arms, and fingers to write. The difficulty your daughter is experiencing may be related to her fine motor skills. Fine motor skills are the small movements that allow us to use our hands and fingers to accomplish tasks like writing, drawing, and buttoning a shirt. Some children are naturally more skilled at these fine motor tasks than others. In the meantime, here are some tips to help your daughter practice her fine motor skills:1. Provide opportunities for your daughter to practice her fine motor skills by engaging in activities that involve the use of small objects, such as using a pencil to draw, coloring, or playing with playdough.2. Play with your daughter! Play is an excellent way to help your daughter develop fine motor skills. Activities like building with blocks, playing with playdough, or playing with a puzzle are great for developing fine motor skills.3. Encourage your daughter to practice writing with a pencil or crayon. Encourage her to use her fingers to guide the writing utensil. This may be easier for her than holding the writing utensil in her hand.4. Encourage your daughter to take breaks from writing. Writing can be tiring for the hands and fingers. Encourage her to rest her hands and fingers, and then return to writing when she feels ready.5. Provide your daughter with a lot of encouragement and support. Remind her that it's okay to make mistakes and that it's a process to develop fine motor skills.6. Consider speaking with your daughter's teacher to see if there are any accommodations that can be made in the classroom to help your daughter succeed with writing. It's possible that she may need a pencil grip or a specific writing tool that would help her write more easily.7. If your daughter continues to struggle with writing, consider speaking with an occupational therapist. An occupational therapist can help your daughter develop the fine motor skills she needs to succeed with writing. They can also provide you with additional tips and strategies to help your daughter practice her fine motor skills at home.8. Be patient! Developing fine motor skills takes time and practice. Encourage your daughter to keep practicing, and she will eventually develop the fine motor skills she needs to succeed with writing. I hope this helps! If you have any other

Hi, I'm glad you're interested in neurofeedback.  It's a relatively new therapy, and there is limited research on its side effects.  However, I've been working with neurofeedback for 20 years and have not seen any negative side effects in my practice.  Some of my clients have reported a decrease in anxiety, depression, and sleep disturbances.  However, I've also had clients who have reported feeling a bit anxious or overwhelmed during the training, but this typically resolves itself after a few sessions.  It's also common for clients to report feeling a bit "wired" or "on edge" after training, but this usually resolves itself within 24 hours.  It's also possible for clients to experience a bit of a "crash" after the training, but this is usually temporary and resolves itself after a few days.  I've had a few clients report a decrease in libido, but this usually resolves itself after a few weeks.  It's also possible for clients to experience a bit of a "brain fog" after training, but this usually resolves itself within a few days.  Overall, the benefits of neurofeedback far outweigh the risks.  If you have any further questions, feel free to ask.  I hope this helps.

Hi, I'm glad you asked. A manic episode is a period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood that lasts at least one week (or less if hospitalization is required). During a manic episode, a person may experience several of the following symptoms: a marked increase in goal-directed activity or activity level, such as talking more than usual or feeling restlessness. The person may have a decrease in need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only a few hours of sleep). They may also have a flight of ideas or the inability to focus on one idea. In some cases, they may have a pressured speech (talking very rapidly). They may have a decrease in inhibitions, such as engaging in inappropriate or risky behavior, such as spending money recklessly or having sex with someone you don't know well. They may also have a marked increase in self-esteem and grandiosity (feeling like they can do anything). A person may also have a decrease in judgment and insight. They may also have psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations or delusions. A person may have a rapid heart rate, increased blood pressure, and a decrease in appetite. A person may also have a history of a manic episode. Depression is not a symptom of a manic episode, but a person may have depression after a manic episode. A manic episode is often preceded by a period of hypomania. A hypomanic episode is a period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood that lasts at least 4 days but less than one week. The symptoms are the same as a manic episode, but they are not as severe. A person may not realize that they are ill or may not seek help. A hypomanic episode is often followed by a depressive episode. I hope this helps. If you have any other questions, please ask. Best of luck to you. Sincerely, Harriet B. Brauner, Ph.D. (Licensed Psychologist)

You're asking about a very important question. I've worked as a psychotherapist for 35 years and I've heard this question many times.  I'll give you my perspective.  In my opinion, the difference between therapy and counseling is the depth of the work.  If you're seeking counseling, you may be looking for someone to talk to about your issues, but you may not be ready to go deeper into your issues.  You may just want to talk about your problems and you may not want to deal with the underlying causes.  In therapy, the work is deeper.  The therapist will work with you to uncover the underlying causes of your issues and help you to work through them.  It's like peeling an onion, you're not just dealing with the surface, but you're going deeper and deeper until you get to the core of the issue.  If you're not ready to go that deep, then counseling may be a good option for you.  If you're ready to work on yourself and you're ready to face your demons, then therapy is a good option.  It's not to say that one is better than the other.  It's just that therapy is a deeper, more intense process.  I hope this helps.  I wish you the best of luck in your search for a therapist.   Please let me know if you have any other questions.

Hi there, I'm here to help.  The terms depression and sadness are often used interchangeably, but they are not the same thing.  Sadness is an emotion that everyone experiences at some point in their lives.  It is a normal response to a loss or a disappointment.  It is a temporary feeling that usually goes away once the circumstances that caused it change or resolve.  Depression, on the other hand, is a mood disorder that is characterized by a persistent feeling of sadness or hopelessness that lasts for weeks, months, or even years.  It can be so severe that it interferes with daily life.  Depression can also include feelings of guilt, shame, worthlessness, and self-blame.  It can be so intense that it affects a person's ability to sleep, eat, and interact with others.  It can also affect a person's concentration, memory, and ability to make decisions.  It can be so severe that it requires professional help.  It is not something that a person can just "snap out of."  It is a serious mental health issue that needs to be treated by a professional.  I hope this information is helpful.  If you have any other questions, please feel free to ask.

Hi, thank you for your question. It is not uncommon for people to have difficulty finding a good match with a therapist.  The first step is to find a therapist who has the experience and credentials that you are looking for.  You can start by asking friends, family members or coworkers if they know of a therapist they would recommend.  You can also look online, check out your insurance company's list of providers or check with your local psychology association for a list of licensed therapists in your area.  Once you have a list of potential therapists, you can start making phone calls to get a sense of their availability, fees, and approach to therapy.  You can also check out their website and social media to get a sense of their approach and what to expect in therapy.  If you have a sense that you would like to work with a particular therapist, you can schedule an initial consultation to get a sense of how you feel about them and to see if they are a good match for you.  You can ask questions about their approach, their experience working with clients with issues similar to yours, and how they will work with you to achieve your goals.  It is also okay to ask if you can talk to previous clients to get a sense of their experience working with them.  In terms of training your therapist, it is a collaborative process.  You should work together to identify your goals and the areas you would like to work on in therapy.  Your therapist will work with you to develop a treatment plan that is tailored to your needs and goals.  You can also ask your therapist if they have any suggestions or recommendations for how to work together to achieve your goals.  It is also okay to express your needs and concerns to your therapist and to let them know if you are not feeling heard or understood.  Your therapist should be able to work with you to address these concerns and to help you feel more comfortable and confident in the therapy process.   I hope this helps.  Best of luck in finding a therapist who is a good match for you.   Sincerely,  Dr. Bethany Marshall, Licensed Psychologist,  www.bethanymarshall.com.

Hi, thank you for your question.  Finding a therapist is a very personal decision and can be a bit of a process. Hi, I'm sorry to hear that you are experiencing depression and anxiety. Depression and anxiety can be very challenging to deal with.  It sounds like you are experiencing a lot of emotional pain and distress.  One of the most important things you can do is seek help from a mental health professional.  They can help you to understand what is causing your depression and anxiety and develop a plan to address them.  In the meantime, here are a few things you can do to help manage your symptoms:1.  Get enough sleep.  Sleep deprivation can exacerbate symptoms of depression and anxiety.  Try to get at least 8 hours of sleep each night.2.  Exercise regularly.  Exercise can help reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety.  You don't have to do anything strenuous, but even a short walk each day can be beneficial.3.  Eat a healthy diet.  Avoid sugary and processed foods and opt for a healthy diet.  You can also consider seeing a registered dietitian to get personalized recommendations.4.  Engage in activities that you enjoy.  This can help distract you from your symptoms and improve your mood.  It's okay if you can't do everything you used to do, but try to find things that you can do.5.  Practice relaxation techniques.  There are many relaxation techniques that can help reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression.  You can try deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation.6.  Seek out social support.  Talk to friends and family members about how you are feeling.  You can also join a support group to connect with others who are going through similar experiences.7.  Consider seeking help from a therapist.  Therapy can provide you with a safe space to talk about your feelings and develop coping skills to manage your symptoms.  I hope these suggestions are helpful.  Please take care of yourself and seek help if you need it.

I'm so sorry to hear that you're feeling uncertain about your relationship. I can only imagine how difficult it is for you to consider the end of a relationship. It takes a lot of courage to consider this, and I want to acknowledge that. 
First, I want to say that you're not alone. Many people struggle with this same question. 
If you're unsure about your relationship, it's likely that you're feeling uncertain about something specific. Is it something specific that's bothering you, or is it a general feeling of uncertainty? 
If you can identify what's bothering you, that might be a good place to start. What are the things that are causing you to feel uncertain about your relationship? Is it a lack of communication, trust, intimacy, or something else? 
If you're feeling uncertain about your relationship, it might be helpful to ask yourself some questions about your feelings and your relationship. For example:
What are my feelings about my partner?
What are my partner's feelings about me?
Do we have a healthy and respectful communication?
Do I feel valued and respected by my partner?
Do I feel safe in my relationship?
Do we have a strong emotional connection?
If you're unsure about your answers to these questions, it might be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your partner. It's okay to express your feelings and concerns. It's okay to say that you're unsure about your relationship and to ask your partner to help you work through your feelings together. 
If you're unsure about your relationship, it might be helpful to take some time to reflect on your feelings and your relationship. Ask yourself what you want from your relationship and what you're looking for in a partner. If you're unsure about your answers to these questions, it might be helpful to seek out the help of a therapist or counselor. A therapist can help you work through your feelings and can provide you with a safe and supportive space to explore your thoughts and feelings. 
Ultimately, deciding whether to end a relationship is a personal decision that only you can make. However, I want to remind you that it's okay to prioritize your own needs and to take care of yourself. You deserve to be in a relationship that makes you feel happy, valued, and respected. If you're unsure about your relationship, it might be helpful to take some time to reflect on your feelings and to consider what you want from your relationship.

Hi there, and thank you for reaching out for support. I'm glad you're seeking help. It's wonderful that you're taking proactive steps to address your concerns. I'll offer some suggestions to help you feel more prepared and confident in managing anxiety.1. Learn about anxiety: Understanding anxiety and its effects can help you better prepare. Read about anxiety, its symptoms, and strategies for managing it. This knowledge will empower you to recognize when you're experiencing anxiety and respond accordingly.2. Familiarize yourself with relaxation techniques: There are various relaxation techniques that can help you calm your mind and body. Some popular techniques include deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, visualization, and mindfulness meditation. Experiment with different techniques to find what works best for you.3. Exercise regularly: Regular physical activity can help reduce anxiety. Find a routine that you enjoy, whether it's walking, running, yoga, or any other form of exercise. This will help you feel more energized and prepared to handle stressful situations.4. Practice self-care: Take care of your physical and emotional needs. Ensure you get enough sleep, eat a balanced diet, and engage in activities that bring you joy. This will help you feel more grounded and better equipped to handle anxiety.5. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or a therapist for support. Sharing your concerns with others can help you feel more connected and less isolated. A therapist can provide you with personalized guidance and support in managing anxiety.6. Consider seeking professional help: If you're experiencing anxiety, it's helpful to seek professional guidance. A therapist can help you develop coping strategies and provide you with support in managing anxiety.7. Be kind to yourself: Remember that it's okay to feel anxious. Acknowledge your feelings and be kind to yourself. Try not to judge yourself for having anxiety, and focus on developing strategies to manage it.8. Travel with a plan: Plan your trips ahead of time, and have a plan in place for managing anxiety. Consider having a support system in place, such as a travel companion or a support hotline, in case you need to talk to someone.9. Consider a travel companion: Having a travel companion can provide you with emotional support and help you feel more connected during your trips.10. Practice self-compassion: Be kind to yourself, and remember that it's okay to make mistakes. Don't be too hard on yourself if you have an anxiety attack. Instead, focus on learning from the experience and finding ways to prevent it from happening again

Hi, I'm so glad you asked this question. Finding the right therapist can be a bit like finding the right pair of shoes. It may take a few tries, but it is well worth the time and effort. Here are some tips for finding the right therapist for you:1. Consider your goals for therapy. What are you hoping to get out of therapy? If you are unsure, then it may be helpful to start with a therapist who can help you clarify your goals and develop a treatment plan.2. Consider the type of therapy that works best for you. If you are looking for a specific type of therapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, then you may want to look for a therapist who specializes in that area.3. Consider your personality. Do you prefer a therapist who is more direct and assertive, or one who is more gentle and empathetic?4. Consider your comfort level with the therapist. If you feel comfortable with the therapist, you are more likely to open up and work with them effectively.5. Consider your budget. Some therapists may charge more than others. If you are on a budget, you may want to look for a therapist who offers sliding scale fees.6. Consider the location of the therapist. Do you prefer to see a therapist in your home, or in their office?7. Consider the therapist's credentials. Do they have experience working with clients with concerns similar to yours?8. Consider the therapist's personality. Do you feel comfortable with them? Do you feel like you can talk to them about anything?If you have found a therapist you are interested in working with, then it is a good idea to ask them a few questions to make sure they are a good fit for you. Here are a few questions you may want to ask:1. What experience do you have working with clients with concerns similar to mine?2. What is your approach to therapy?3. What can I expect from our sessions?4. How will we work together to develop a treatment plan?5. How often will we meet, and how long will our sessions be?6. How will we know when my goals have been met?7. How will we handle any challenges that arise during our work together?8. How will we end our therapy when my goals have been met?I hope these tips are helpful in finding the right therapist for you. Good luck!

Hi, I'm glad you're taking the time to ask about how to find a good therapist.  You are absolutely right that finding the right therapist can be a bit like finding the right pair of shoes.  It's hard to know what will fit you best unless you try a few different options.  Here are a few tips that may help you find the right therapist for you:1.  Ask around - ask friends, family members, or coworkers if they have any recommendations.  You can also ask your doctor or your insurance provider for a referral.  You can also check with your state's licensing board to see if there have been any complaints filed against the therapist you're considering.2.  Look at the therapist's credentials - make sure they have the right education and training for what you need.  For example, if you're dealing with anxiety or depression, you may want a therapist who has experience working with these issues.  If you're dealing with trauma, you may want a therapist who has experience with trauma and has training in trauma-informed care.3.  Look at the therapist's approach - do they use a specific approach or technique that you're interested in? Hi there. I'm so glad you reached out to ask this question. It's not uncommon for partners to feel like they are the ones who are always listening and that the other person never listens to them. I want to ask you a question. Have you ever stopped to consider that you may be the one who is listening more because you want to hear what your husband is saying? I'm not saying that you don't want to hear him, but perhaps you are listening more because you want to hear what he has to say. You may be a very empathetic person and you are naturally inclined to listen more. This is not a bad thing, but it can be a challenge for you to ask for what you need in return. I would encourage you to take a moment to reflect on what you need from your husband in terms of listening. What do you need him to hear from you? What do you need him to say in response to you? Once you have a clear idea of what you need, I would encourage you to ask him to listen to you in a specific way. For example, you might say, "I need you to listen to me for the next 10 minutes without interrupting me. I need you to hear me out and then we can discuss this further." It's okay if your husband doesn't understand what you need. It's okay if he doesn't want to listen to you right now. But what's not okay is that you don't ask him to listen to you. You deserve to be heard. You deserve to be understood. And you deserve to be respected. I hope this helps. I hope you and your husband can work on this together. I hope you have a great day.

Hi, and thanks for your question. I'm glad you're in a program that will help you grow and develop. Being shy is common and not something that you should be ashamed of. Here are some suggestions that might help you feel more confident:1.  Prepare well:  Prepare thoroughly for your presentations. Do your homework, practice your presentation, and rehearse your delivery. This will help you feel more comfortable and prepared, which will give you more confidence.2.  Use positive self-talk:  When you feel anxious or nervous, your mind often starts to tell you that you're not good enough or that you'll fail. Challenge these negative thoughts with positive affirmations. Tell yourself that you're well-prepared and that you have a lot to offer.3.  Use relaxation techniques:  Relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization can help you calm your nerves and feel more relaxed.4.  Focus on the message:  Remember that you're not speaking just to impress your audience, you're speaking to share your ideas and insights. Focus on the message you're trying to convey, rather than on how you're coming across.5.  Seek support:  Talk to friends, family members, or a therapist about your anxiety. They may be able to offer you advice or support that will help you feel more confident.6.  Take small steps:  If you're really struggling, start small. Begin by speaking in small groups or to a small audience. Gradually work your way up to larger groups.7.  Practice, practice, practice:  The more you practice, the more comfortable you'll become.8.  Use positive visualization:  Imagine yourself giving a successful presentation. Visualize your audience applauding and being supportive. Visualize yourself feeling confident and comfortable.9.  Seek support from your instructor:  If you're struggling with anxiety, talk to your instructor. They may be able to offer you support, advice, or accommodations to help you feel more comfortable.10.  Consider a support group:  If you're really struggling, consider joining a support group for people who are also struggling with public speaking anxiety. They may be able to offer you support and advice that will help you feel more confident. I hope these suggestions help you feel more confident in your presentations. Best of luck.

It sounds like you are feeling a lot of shame and guilt about the situations you found yourself in.  Shame and guilt are very different emotions.  Shame is about what you think about yourself and guilt is about what you think about what you did.  You can't control how others think about you, but you can control how you think about yourself.  If you can't forgive yourself, you might want to consider writing down all of the things you are beating yourself up about and then challenge each one of them.  Ask yourself if they are really true and if they are, are there any things that you can do to prevent them from happening in the future?  If they are not true, then you can let them go.  It's also helpful to practice self-compassion.  You are human and humans make mistakes.  You are not a bad person because you made a mistake.  You are a person who made a mistake.  It's also helpful to consider how you would treat a friend in a similar situation.  You would probably be supportive and understanding, right?  It's okay to be kind to yourself too.  It sounds like you are beating yourself up pretty badly, and that can be hard to do.  You might want to consider talking to a therapist about this.  They can help you work through your feelings and develop a more compassionate way of thinking about yourself.

It's great that you're thinking about how to find the right therapist for you. Here are some tips on how to find the right therapist for you, and how to "train" them to give you what you need from treatment:
1. Before you start looking for a therapist, it's a good idea to think about what you want to get out of therapy. What are your goals? What are you hoping to achieve? What are your concerns? What are you hoping to work through? This will help you know what to look for in a therapist. 
2. When you start looking for a therapist, ask friends, family, or your primary care physician for recommendations. You can also check with your insurance provider to see who is covered under your plan. You can also check with your local mental health organization or online directories such as Psychology Today.
3. When you find a therapist, check their credentials. Do they have a degree in a field related to mental health? Are they licensed? Do they have experience working with people with issues like yours?
4. When you meet with a therapist for the first time, pay attention to how you feel. Do you feel comfortable? Do you feel heard? Do you feel understood? Do you feel like you can trust them?
5. During your first session, ask the therapist questions. What is their approach? What kind of therapy will they use? How long will sessions last? What is their policy on canceling or rescheduling sessions?
6. During your first session, pay attention to how the therapist responds to you. Do they seem to be listening to you? Do they seem to be understanding what you're saying? Do they seem to be validating your feelings?
7. If you feel like you're not a good fit with the therapist, it's okay to try someone else. It's okay to ask questions. It's okay to seek out a second opinion. It's okay to leave therapy altogether if you feel like it's not working for you.
8. Remember that therapy is a process. It's a process of getting to know yourself, your therapist, and your therapist's approach. It's a process of building trust, of learning to communicate effectively, and of working through difficult emotions. It's okay to take your time. It's okay to be patient.

Hi, and thanks for your question. Crying is a normal and healthy response to therapy, and it's not uncommon for people to cry during therapy sessions. Best regards, Jeanne Thomas, LCSW, PCC.

Hello,Thank you for reaching out to me. I am so sorry to hear about what you are going through. You are right, this can be dangerous. I would recommend that you do not try to confront her about this. The reason is that she will likely deny it, and you may not believe her, and then she will become angry. If you are right, she will then deny that she was angry, and you will be left with the guilt of being right. It is hard to deal with a person who lies about everything. It is hard to trust them, and it is hard to know what to believe. If you are able, try to stay out of her life, and if she asks for help, offer it to her. If she asks for help, she may be willing to listen. If she is not willing to listen, you can't force her to change. I hope this helps. Sincerely, Lynn Lyons, LCSW, CEDS-CDT

I recommend that you talk to a mental health professional who can help you identify what's causing your anxiety and develop coping skills to manage it. I hope this helps and I wish you the best of luck in your journey.  Take care.

Hi, I'm so glad you asked! Self-management is a term used in the mental health field to describe the ability to take care of yourself. It involves managing your thoughts, emotions, and behaviors in a healthy way. Self-management can be thought of as the opposite of self-harm. People who practice self-management take care of themselves by doing things that help them feel good, like exercise, eating well, getting enough sleep, and spending time with people they love. They also manage their thoughts and emotions in a way that is healthy and positive. They might practice mindfulness, meditation, or talk to someone they trust about how they feel. Self-management is a skill that can be learned with practice and patience. It takes time and effort, but it can help people feel better and live a more fulfilling life. I hope this helps. If you're struggling with self-harm, I would encourage you to seek out a therapist or counselor who can help you learn self-management skills. You can find a therapist by asking your doctor for a referral, or by searching online for therapists in your area. You can also reach out to the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255) for support. Is there anything else you'd like to know about self-management? How has self-management helped you? What challenges have you faced in practicing self-management? I'm here to listen and offer support.

I'm so sorry to hear that you're feeling this way.  It's normal to feel sad, confused, and unsure about what to do.  First, I want you to know that you're not alone.  Many people have been in your shoes before.  It's okay to feel this way and to be unsure about what to do.  This is a normal part of the process.  If you're feeling overwhelmed, it may be helpful to reach out to a therapist or counselor who can help you sort through your feelings.  In the meantime, here are some suggestions that may help:1)  Take care of yourself.  Make sure you're eating well, exercising, and getting enough sleep.  It's easy to neglect these things when we're feeling stressed and unsure about what to do, but taking care of yourself will help you feel more grounded and better equipped to handle whatever comes next.2)  Reach out to friends and family members who you trust.  Talking to someone you trust can help you feel heard and understood, and they may be able to offer you some advice or support.3)  Consider talking to your partner about your feelings.  It may be scary to do this, but it's possible that talking to him about your feelings could help you both understand each other better and figure out a way to move forward.4)  If you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about what to do, it may be helpful to take some time to think about what you want.  What are your goals?  What do you want to happen?  What are you willing to do to make that happen?  It's okay to take your time and figure out what you want.  It's okay to say no to things that don't feel right for you.  It's okay to say yes to things that feel right for you.I hope these suggestions are helpful.  Remember, you're not alone and you're not crazy for feeling this way.  It's okay to be unsure and to feel overwhelmed.  It's okay to take your time and figure out what you want.  You got this!

Yes, people can stabilize a mental illness simply with medication alone. However, medication is often used in conjunction with other treatments like therapy, self-help, and lifestyle changes. There are many different types of therapy, so you can try different types to find what works best for you. Medication can help you manage symptoms and improve your quality of life. It can also help you work with a therapist to address underlying issues that may have contributed to your mental health problems. It's completely normal to feel numb after a traumatic event. The numbness can be a protective mechanism to help you cope with the pain and trauma. It's like your brain is "numbing" itself to the pain to prevent you from feeling it. You may have a lot of anger or other feelings that are not surfacing yet. You may also be in a state of denial. Denial is a defense mechanism that people use to avoid the pain of the trauma. The numbness can also be a sign of depression. Depression can cause you to feel numb and disconnected from your feelings. There are many ways to help you feel more connected to your feelings. I would recommend that you talk to a therapist about your feelings and experiences. A therapist can help you work through your feelings and emotions. You may also want to consider a support group for survivors of sexual assault. This can be a safe place for you to talk about your feelings with others who have gone through a similar experience. I would also recommend that you talk to your primary care physician about your feelings. They can help you determine if you are experiencing depression and can prescribe medication if necessary. There are also support hotlines that you can call. The National Sexual Assault Hotline is available 24/7. You can call them at 1-800-656-HOPE (4673). The National Domestic Violence Hotline is also available 24/7. You can call them at 1-800-799-7233. The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is also available 24/7. You can call them at 1-800-273-TALK (8255). I hope this helps. It takes a lot of courage to talk about something as difficult as this. You are brave for reaching out. I hope you get the support you need.

I am so sorry to hear about your experiences. It's understandable that you would feel numb, but it's not a sociopath condition. The numbness you are experiencing is a way of coping with the trauma. It's called dissociation. When we dissociate, we numb ourselves to the pain and the emotions that come with it. This is a way of protecting ourselves from feeling too much pain. However, it is not a healthy way of coping, and it can lead to further trauma and difficulty in feeling and expressing emotions. One way to start feeling again is to start small. It may start with something as simple as feeling a sensation in your body, like the feeling of your feet on the ground or the sensation of the air on your skin. It may be helpful to start a journal and write down the sensations you feel. This will help you become more aware of your body and the sensations that you are feeling. Another way is to start to feel emotions through creative expression. This can be through art, music, writing, or any other form of creative expression that you enjoy. It's also helpful to talk to a therapist about your experiences and your feelings. A therapist can help you work through your feelings and help you learn to express them in a healthy way. I hope this helps. Please feel free to write back if you have any further questions.

It's not uncommon to experience feelings of inadequacy or imposter syndrome in graduate school.  This is especially true when you're doing well in your program and are in a high-achieving program.  One way to think about it is that you may be experiencing a bit of a confidence gap.  You know you're doing well, but you're not feeling confident in your abilities.  There are a couple of things you can do to help bridge that gap.  First, think about the skills you have and the things you're good at.  It's easy to get caught up in the things we're not good at, but it's also important to remember the things we are good at.  Second, remind yourself that everyone feels this way sometimes.  Even the most confident people have moments of doubt.  Third, take care of yourself.  Exercise, eat well, get enough sleep, and take time for yourself.  Lastly, talk to someone you trust about how you're feeling.  It's always helpful to get a different perspective.  It may be helpful to talk to a therapist who can help you work through these feelings of inadequacy.  It's a common phenomenon and it's not something to be ashamed of.

Hi, and thanks for your question. It is great that you are motivated to quit smoking for the health of your baby. Here are some suggestions that may help you to quit smoking:1. You may want to consult with your doctor or a nurse about nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) or a prescription medication that may help you to quit smoking. 2. You may also want to look into counseling or a support group to help you quit smoking. 3. You may also want to write down the reasons that you want to quit smoking and post them somewhere where you can see them. This can help you to stay motivated. 4. You may also want to look into the quit smoking apps that are available for your phone. There are many free apps that may help you to quit smoking. 5. You may also want to talk to your family and friends about your desire to quit smoking. They may be able to offer you support and encouragement. 6. You may also want to look into the reasons why you smoke. Is it to relieve stress? Is it to socialize with friends? Is it to relieve boredom? You may want to find alternative ways to relieve stress, socialize, and relieve boredom. 7. You may also want to find a hobby that you enjoy and do it regularly. This may help to distract you from the desire to smoke. 8. You may also want to reward yourself for each day that you don't smoke. This may help you to stay motivated. 9. You may also want to consider that you are not alone in your desire to quit smoking. There are many people who are trying to quit smoking. You may want to look into a support group or a community of people who are trying to quit smoking. 10. You may also want to look into the reasons why you started smoking in the first place. You may want to talk to a therapist about your reasons for smoking and how to overcome them. I hope these suggestions are helpful to you. Good luck with your efforts to quit smoking.

I am so glad you asked! Dealing with stress can be challenging, but there are many things you can do to manage it. First, I would like you to know that it's normal to experience stress. Stress is a natural response to a perceived threat or demand, and it is a part of life. The key is learning how to manage it in a healthy way. Here are a few things you can do to help manage your stress:1. Take care of your physical health. Make sure you are getting enough sleep, eating well, and exercising regularly. A healthy body can help you feel better when you are stressed.2. Practice relaxation techniques. There are many things you can do to help you relax, such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, visualization, and meditation. You can find videos on YouTube or other online resources that can guide you through these techniques.3. Find healthy ways to express your emotions. When we are stressed, we can feel overwhelmed and angry. It's helpful to find healthy ways to express these feelings, such as talking to a trusted friend or family member, journaling, or writing in a diary.4. Learn to say no. It's okay to say no to things that you don't want to do or that you don't have time for. It's okay to set boundaries and prioritize your own needs.5. Seek help when you need it. If you are feeling overwhelmed and you don't know how to manage your stress, it's okay to seek help from a therapist. A therapist can help you identify the causes of your stress and provide you with coping strategies.6. Practice gratitude. Focusing on the things you are grateful for can help you feel better and reduce stress.7. Take breaks. Taking a break from a stressful situation or activity can help you feel better and recharge.8. Learn to forgive yourself and others. Holding onto resentment and anger can increase stress and make it harder to manage. Practicing forgiveness can help you feel better and reduce stress.9. Seek out a support system. Having a support system, such as friends, family, or a support group, can help you feel less alone and more supported.10. Practice self-care. Taking care of yourself is important. Engage in activities that bring you joy and make you feel good about yourself. I hope these suggestions are helpful. Remember, managing stress is a process and it takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and seek help when you need it.

Hi there, thank you for reaching out.  It sounds like you're feeling a little insecure in your relationship.  This is not uncommon.  We all have doubts about our partners at times.  The question is, what are you doing with these feelings?  Are you talking about them with your boyfriend, or are you keeping them inside?  If you are talking about them with him, he may be able to help you to feel better about things.  If you are keeping them inside, you may be creating a bigger problem than you need to.  Try to talk to him about your feelings.  He may be able to reassure you that you have nothing to worry about.  If he is hiding something from you, he may not be the right person for you to be with.  If you don't feel like you can talk to him about your feelings, you may want to consider counseling.  A therapist can help you to work through these feelings and to figure out what to do about them.  It's not uncommon for people to be insecure in a relationship.  It's how you handle those feelings that matters.  You can either work through them and make the relationship stronger, or you can let them consume you and lead to the end of the relationship.  I wish you the best of luck in figuring out what to do about your feelings.  I hope this helps.  If you have any other questions or concerns, please feel free to ask.

I think it's completely normal that you're feeling frustrated and disappointed.  Alzheimer's is a very difficult disease to deal with, both for the person with the disease and for those of us who care about them.  It's not uncommon for individuals with Alzheimer's to have trouble remembering important information, including their own children, so it's not likely that she's ignoring you on purpose.  It's also not uncommon for individuals with Alzheimer's to have difficulty with impulse control, so it's possible that she's saying things that she doesn't mean or that she regrets later.  It's also possible that she's experiencing a lot of anxiety or fear, and that's causing her to act in ways that are not typical of her usual behavior.  It's hard to know what's going on without knowing more about your mom's specific situation.  Have you talked to her doctor or a geriatric psychiatrist about your concerns?  They may be able to give you some insight into what's going on with your mom and what you can do to help her.  I hope this helps.  Good luck.

Hi,It's great that you're taking the initiative to care for your brother.  You can't force your brother into a mental health facility, but you can encourage him to go and offer to accompany him.  If he's not willing, you could look into a 72-hour hold in a hospital.  You can also look into the laws in your state to see if there are any other options.  If he is in danger of harming himself or others, you can call 911 and have him taken in for a 72-hour hold.  This will give you and your brother a chance to talk and figure out what he wants to do.  You can also look into your state's mental health laws and see if there are any other options.  It's always best to talk to a mental health professional before doing anything.  If you can't get your brother to go to a mental health facility, you may need to get a court order to have him involuntarily committed.  This should be a last resort, as it can be very stressful for both you and your brother.  You can also look into a court-appointed conservator to help your brother.  This person can help him with his finances and other things.  You can also talk to a lawyer to see what your options are.  It's best to have a lawyer who specializes in mental health law.  I hope this helps.  I know it's a tough situation, but you can do this.

I am so glad you're interested in facing your fears. Facing your fears is a great way to build confidence, self-esteem, and self-awareness. There are many different ways to face your fears, but it's best to find what works for you. Here are a few suggestions:1) If the fear is a specific, tangible thing (like spiders or heights), try facing it in a safe, controlled environment. For example, if you're afraid of spiders, you could go to a zoo or a pet store where you can see spiders safely. If you're afraid of heights, you could start by standing on the edge of a low balcony or a small hill and work your way up to higher and higher heights.2) If the fear is an abstract thing (like fear of failure or fear of being hurt), try to identify what you're afraid of. For example, are you afraid of failing because you think you'll be a disappointment to yourself or others? Are you afraid of being hurt because you think you'll be hurt by someone you love? Once you know what you're afraid of, you can work on addressing the root of your fear.3) If you're afraid of a specific situation, try to imagine yourself in that situation. For example, if you're afraid of public speaking, imagine yourself giving a speech in front of a crowd. Imagine the crowd listening to you, and imagine yourself feeling confident and proud of what you're saying. Practice this until you feel more comfortable with the idea of public speaking.4) If you're afraid of a specific person or group of people, try to identify what you're afraid of. For example, are you afraid of your boss because you think they're mean or critical? Are you afraid of your parents because you think they're disappointed in you? Once you know what you're afraid of, you can work on addressing the root of your fear.5) If you're afraid of a specific memory or experience, try to talk about it with a trusted friend or family member. Sometimes talking about what happened can help you process it and move past it.6) If you're afraid of something you can't control (like natural disasters or illness), try to focus on things you can control. For example, you can't control whether or not a natural disaster will happen, but you can control how you prepare for it. You do not have too many issues to address in counseling.  It is a great idea to work on all of these issues.  They all interconnect with each other.  For example, if you are a breast cancer survivor, you may be more likely to experience anxiety and depression.  If you have a history of sexual abuse, you may experience low self-esteem.  If you have a history of depression, you may have difficulty sleeping.  The key is to start with the issue that you feel most comfortable with and to work your way through them.  It may be helpful to start with the issue that you feel the most anxious about.  This may help you to feel more comfortable with the other issues.  I hope this helps.  I wish you the best of luck.  Sincerely, Dr. Carole A. Lambert, Ph.D. Licensed Psychologist, PA.

Hello and thank you for your question. I'm so sorry to hear that you're dealing with a chronic illness. It's understandable that you're feeling alone and sad. I think that the basic skills that a good counselor should have are:1) Empathy: the ability to understand and connect with others.2) Active listening: the ability to truly listen to others and hear what they are saying.3) Self-awareness: the ability to understand oneself and one's own emotions, thoughts, and behaviors.4) Compassion: the ability to care about others and be kind to them.5) Non-judgmental attitude: the ability to not judge others, but to accept them as they are.6) Flexibility: the ability to be able to adjust to different situations and circumstances.7) Open-mindedness: the ability to be open to new ideas and perspectives.8) Good communication skills: the ability to communicate effectively with others.9) Trustworthiness: the ability to be trusted by others.10) Strong boundaries: the ability to set and maintain healthy boundaries with others.11) Strong self-care: the ability to take care of oneself, physically, emotionally, and spiritually.12) Strong professional ethics: the ability to practice according to the ethics of the profession.13) Strong professional skills: the ability to use the skills and techniques of the profession to help others.14) Strong support system: the ability to have a strong support system, including a support system of peers, mentors, and supervisors.15) Strong critical thinking skills: the ability to think critically and solve problems effectively.16) Strong time management skills: the ability to manage one's time effectively.17) Strong record keeping skills: the ability to keep accurate and complete records.18) Strong crisis management skills: the ability to handle crisis situations effectively.19) Strong self-reflection skills: the ability to reflect on one's own practice and to make changes as needed.20) Strong ability to work with diverse populations: the ability to work with people from different backgrounds, cultures, and ages.21) Strong ability to work with diverse issues: the ability to work with people who have different issues and problems.22) Strong ability to work in a team: the ability to work with others as part of a team.23) Strong ability to work with technology: the ability to use technology to communicate with clients and to document client information.24) Strong ability to work with the law: the ability to understand and follow the laws and regulations that govern the profession.25) Strong ability to work with insurance companies: the ability to work with insurance companies to secure payment

Hi, I'm so sorry to hear that you're struggling with seasonal depression. It's not uncommon, especially in the winter. In fact, it's estimated that up to 10 million people in the US experience Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) every year.  It's a form of depression that occurs at the same time every year, typically during the winter months when there is less sunlight.  The lack of sunlight can disrupt your internal clock and affect your mood.  It's not something to be ashamed of.  If you're struggling with it, you're not alone.  Here are some tips to help you cope with SAD: 1.  Get some sunlight:  While it may be cold and dark outside, take a walk outside each day.  Even a 10-minute walk can make a difference.  Open your curtains to let sunlight in.  Use a light therapy lamp if possible. 2.  Exercise:  Regular exercise can help reduce symptoms of depression.  Exercise releases endorphins, which are chemicals that make us feel good.  It's a natural mood booster.  If you're struggling to get motivated, start small.  Take a short walk each day.  You can always increase the length and intensity as you feel more energized.  3.  Stay connected with friends and family:  Social support is essential to managing SAD.  Reach out to friends and family.  Join a club or group that interests you.  4.  Seek professional help:  If you're experiencing symptoms of depression, seek help.  You don't have to go through this alone.  There are people who care about you and want to help.  You can start by talking to your primary care physician or a mental health professional.  They can help you develop a treatment plan that works for you.  5.  Get enough sleep:  Getting enough sleep is essential to managing SAD.  Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time each day.  Establish a bedtime routine that helps you relax.  6.  Eat a healthy diet:  Eating a healthy diet can help improve your mood.  Focus on eating fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats.  Limit your intake of sugary and processed foods.

Hi, I'm so sorry to hear about your mother's diagnosis. Alzheimer's can be a really tough disease to deal with. It's not uncommon for people with Alzheimer's to act in ways that are frustrating and upsetting for their caregivers. The guilt you're feeling is a natural response to feeling helpless and frustrated. It's also a good thing that you're acknowledging that feeling! One thing you might want to try is to not take your mother's behavior personally. Instead of getting frustrated, you could try to see it as a symptom of her disease. Another thing you might want to try is to not try to change her behavior. Instead of getting frustrated when she asks for something that you know she'll never need or use, you could try to just give it to her and then let it go. If she asks for something silly, you could say "Mom, I'm not sure you'll need that, but I'll get it for you." Then, you could put it in a place where you can easily find it, so she can have it if she needs it. If she asks for something that you know she'll never use, you could say "Mom, I'm not sure that's something you need. Would you like me to get something else for you?" If she becomes upset, you could say "Mom, I know this is hard for you. I'm here to support you. Can we find something else to do?" If you're feeling overwhelmed, you might want to talk to a therapist. I'm not a therapist, but I can recommend a few things you might want to consider doing to help you cope with this situation. 1.  Ask your mother's doctor about medication that might help her with her behavior.2.  Ask a social worker about resources in your area for Alzheimer's patients and their caregivers.3.  Ask your mother's doctor about support groups in your area for people who are caring for a family member with Alzheimer's.4.  Ask your mother's doctor about adult day care programs in your area. I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions. Best regards, Dr. K

Hi, and thank you for reaching out. It's completely normal to feel overwhelmed with life's stressors. There are several things you can do to help manage stress. First, it's helpful to identify what your triggers are. For example, are you worried about money because you're living paycheck to paycheck, or because you're worried you're not making enough money? Are you worried about work because you're overwhelmed with your job, or because you're worried about job security? Identifying your triggers will help you know where to start. Once you know what triggers your anxiety, you can start to brainstorm ways to address those triggers. For example, if you're worried about money, you could start by making a budget, or cutting back on unnecessary expenses. If you're worried about work, you could talk to your boss about your workload, or look into other job opportunities. If you're worried about your kids, you could start by talking to a therapist about what's going on, or finding a support group of other parents who are going through similar things. If you're worried about maintaining a household, you could start by breaking down the tasks into smaller, manageable chunks, or finding ways to delegate tasks to others in your household. Sometimes, anxiety can be a sign that we're trying to control things that are outside of our control. When we're feeling anxious, it's helpful to practice mindfulness and remind ourselves that we can't control everything, and that's okay. It's also helpful to practice self-care, such as exercise, meditation, or spending time with loved ones. I hope this helps, and I wish you all the best. Best regards, Dr. B.

Hi, I'm glad you reached out.  It takes a lot of courage to admit that we're struggling with something.  It's normal to feel this way after a breakup, especially if it was a long-term relationship.  I want you to know that you're not alone in this.  Many people have been in your shoes and have come out the other side.  The first thing I want to say is that you are strong and capable.  You got through this relationship and you can get through this breakup.  It's going to take time, but you can do it.  Here are some suggestions to help you move on:1) Give yourself time to grieve.  It's normal to feel sad and to grieve the loss of a relationship.  Allow yourself to feel these feelings.  It's okay to cry and to be sad.  Just don't get stuck in the sadness.  Allow yourself to feel it and then let it go.2) Take care of yourself.  You need to take care of your physical, emotional, and spiritual self.  Eat well, exercise, get enough sleep, and take time to relax.  You also need to take time to do things that bring you joy and make you happy.  This is a great time to try new things and explore new places.3) Practice self-compassion.  Be kind to yourself and try not to be too hard on yourself.  Remember that you did the best you could with the resources you had at the time.  You made mistakes, but you also made good choices.  Don't beat yourself up over the mistakes.  You are human and you are doing the best you can.4) Reach out to friends and family.  It's okay to ask for help.  Reach out to people who care about you and who will support you.  It's also okay to ask for professional help if you need it.  Therapy can be a great way to work through your feelings and to develop coping strategies.5) Practice forgiveness.  Forgive yourself and others.  It's hard to let go of the anger and resentment, but it's an important part of healing.  Remember that everyone makes mistakes and everyone has flaws.  It's okay to have flaws and it's okay to make mistakes.  It's how we learn

The anxiety disorders, including GAD, are believed to be complex conditions that are influenced by a combination of genetic, environmental, and psychological factors. The exact causes of GAD are not yet known, but research suggests that it is a condition that may run in families. People with a family history of anxiety disorders are more likely to develop an anxiety disorder themselves. For example, if you have a first-degree relative (parent or sibling) with GAD, your risk of developing GAD is increased. This risk is increased even more if you have multiple relatives with anxiety disorders. This is true for other anxiety disorders, including panic disorder, social phobia, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).However, GAD is not directly inherited from parents to children. Rather, it is believed that a combination of genetic and environmental factors may contribute to the development of GAD in an individual. If you have a family history of anxiety disorders, you may be more likely to develop an anxiety disorder, but this is not a guarantee. It is also important to note that GAD can be caused by a variety of factors, including life experiences, personality traits, and other health conditions. If you have a family history of anxiety disorders, you may be more likely to experience anxiety and stress, but you can still develop GAD if you have no family history of anxiety disorders.

Hi,The fact that you are taking medications for your panic attacks means you are addressing the issue in a healthy way.  However, I would caution you to consider why you want to move in with her.  Is it because you are anxious about being away from her?  Or is it because you want to be closer to her?  If it is the latter, then it could be a healthy choice.  If it is the former, then it could be a sign of a deeper issue that you need to address.  If you are not addressing the underlying anxiety, then moving in with her may only serve to temporarily alleviate your anxiety, and it will likely return once you are no longer with her.  I would encourage you to consider therapy to address your anxiety.  It is possible that there are other factors contributing to your anxiety that can be addressed in therapy.  I would also encourage you to have an open and honest conversation with your girlfriend about your anxiety and how you are feeling.  It is possible that she is not aware of how you are feeling, and it is possible that she can offer you support and understanding.  It is also possible that she may be feeling anxious as well.  It is never a bad idea to be honest with your partner about your feelings and to work together to address them.  It is also never a bad idea to consider therapy together.  You may find that addressing your anxiety will also help you to have a healthier relationship with your girlfriend.  It is also possible that you are feeling anxious because of other issues that need to be addressed.  If you are not addressing these issues, then moving in with her may only serve to temporarily alleviate your anxiety.  I would encourage you to consider therapy to address the underlying issues.  I hope this helps.  Best, Jeff Zimmerman, LCSW, LCADC, CADC-II.

Hi, and thanks for your question. I'm glad you're seeking help and support. Binge eating can be a difficult cycle to break, but there are several strategies that may help. First, consider seeking help from a therapist or counselor who specializes in eating disorders. They can help you develop a treatment plan that addresses your physical, emotional, and behavioral issues. They can also help you learn more about your eating patterns and triggers. It may be helpful to keep a food diary to track when you eat, what you eat, and how you feel before, during, and after eating. This can help you identify patterns and triggers. In addition to therapy, there are some coping strategies you can use to help you manage stress and your eating. First, learn to recognize your triggers. What causes you to feel stressed? Is it a specific situation or a feeling? Once you know what triggers your stress, you can develop a plan to deal with it. If you feel stressed, try to engage in a relaxing activity such as taking a walk, practicing yoga, or listening to music. If you feel the urge to binge eat, try to distract yourself by doing something else. Go for a walk, call a friend, or engage in a hobby. If you do give in to the urge to binge, try not to beat yourself up over it. Instead, try to learn from the experience and think about what you could do differently next time. It may also be helpful to practice self-care. Take care of your physical health by eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and getting enough sleep. Also, practice self-compassion and self-forgiveness. Don't be too hard on yourself. Lastly, try to practice mindfulness. Mindfulness is the practice of being present in the moment and paying attention to your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This can help you become more aware of your thoughts and feelings and help you make healthier choices. I hope these suggestions are helpful. I recommend seeking help from a therapist or counselor for additional support and guidance. Best regards, Carol.
